title: Git: deletion marker in the gutter disappears when folding adjacent regions

labels.name: new release
labels.description: Issues found in a recent release of VS Code

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.99.2 (user setup) 4949701c880d4bdb949e3c0e6b400288da7f474b
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create a file `test.html` with the contents below in a Git repository
2. stage the file
3. delete the `between` line
4. fold region 1

```html
<!-- #region 1 -->
1
<!-- #endregion -->
between
<!-- #region 2 -->
2
<!-- #endregion -->
```

Expected: regardless of whether region 1 and/or 2 are folded, the red marker in the gutter is always visible, as the deleted line is part of neither region
Actual: when region 1 is folded, the red marker is invisible

- Version: 1.99.2 (system setup)

- Date: 2025-04-10T01:21:25.295Z
- Electron: 34.3.2
- ElectronBuildId: 11161073
- Chromium: 132.0.6834.210
- Node.js: 20.18.3

When `git.discardUntrackedChangesToTrash` is enabled (default), you discard changes in untracked file and VS Code failed to move file to trash it just show error without providing option to delete file permanently, as it happens with normal file delete operation when VS Code failed to move file to trash.

title: VS Code Server Not Detecting Custom Environment Variables for Old Linux Workaround

labels.name: new release
labels.description: Issues found in a recent release of VS Code

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->

<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

- VS Code Version: 1.99.2 (user setup)
- 提交: 4949701c880d4bdb949e3c0e6b400288da7f474b
- 日期: 2025-04-10T01:21:25.295Z
- Electron: 34.3.2
- ElectronBuildId: 11161073
- Chromium: 132.0.6834.210
- Node.js: 20.18.3
- V8: 13.2.152.41-electron.0
- OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100
**- Linux Distribution: ubuntu 18.04**  

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Built and installed a **glibc 2.28** and “patchelf” following the guide at https://blog.csdn.net/qq_33968692/article/details/146191922
2. Added the following environment variables to ~/.bashrc:
``` bash
export VSCODE_SERVER_CUSTOM_GLIBC_LINKER="$HOME/.local/opt/glibc-2.28/lib/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2"
export VSCODE_SERVER_CUSTOM_GLIBC_PATH="$HOME/.local/opt/glibc-2.28/lib:/usr/lib"
export VSCODE_SERVER_PATCHELF_PATH=$(which patchelf)
```
3. Verified the variables are properly exported in the terminal
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/dbd850e7-0835-40c7-a831-5dc73eb40b3b)
4. Attempted to connect to the remote server

**Expected Behavior:** VS Code Server should detect and use the custom paths specified in the environment variables.

**Actual Behavior:** According to server logs, VS Code Server doesn't attempt to detect or use these environment variables.

**Debugging Information:** I've examined the output logs and don't see any indication that VS Code Server is attempting to read these environment variables. 

Could you provide guidance on:
- How to properly confirm the variables are being detected?
- Are there specific log files I should examine to determine why the variables aren't being recognized?
- Is there a specific process for activating this workaround beyond setting the environment variables?

Additional Context: This issue appears similar to what other users  @zhangjy859 have reported when trying to use VS Code Remote on older Linux distributions. Any guidance on debugging or additional troubleshooting steps would be greatly appreciated.

title: Explorer: Ctrl + Drag-and-drop file does not copy file
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.99.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 24.04.2 LTS

Steps to reproduce:

1a. Hold Ctrl, then click and hold on a file in the explorer.
1b. Click and hold on a file, then hold Ctrl.
2. Drag the file to a new location and release.

Expected results:

1. The cursor displays the plus-icon.
2. When the file is released, the file is copied to the new location.

Actual results:
1. The cursor displays the move-icon.
2. When the file is released, a dialog pops up to confirm *moving* the file.

Additional notes:

The "Help > Report Issue" dialog in VS Code did not auto-fill the report with the information I wrote. I had to copy it manually.

title: TreeSitter breaking on large paste
body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. enable TypeScript treesitter
2. open TS file (with code in it)
3. delete all code or press ctrl+a
4. ctrl+v paste large amount of TS code
5. notice only semantic highlighting working
and some tokens from before the paste can sometimes be seen in different locations
and the minimap doesn't initially update


https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/330b0106-3341-4e16-b940-b1260c3c9b06

[file](https://github.com/RedCMD/TmLanguage-Syntax-Highlighter/blob/main/src/extension.ts)
happened with all tested files (if big enough)

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
- VS Code Version: 1.99.2 and https://insiders.vscode.dev/
- OS Version: Windows 11

cc @alexr00

title: MAKE DIFFS SELECTABLE AGAIN
body: In the git diff view under the source control panel you can no longer select lines/text from your git diffs. This is complete shit. I think I speak for thousands, possibly hundreds of thousands, of devs by expressing my abject rage at the new feature that looks like the attacked screenshot when you click anywhere within this view. It's honestly one of the most disappointing and frustrating features to ever be introduced into a software that I regularly use and, I might sincerely be converted to Neovim if it is not removed.

<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

When using the `vscode.git/clone` uri handler, we'd like for it to open the README.md file automatically if one is present. Perhaps this behavior could be controlled with a query parameter flag.

`vscode-insiders://vscode.git/clone?url=https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-remote-try-node&openReadme=true`

We'd also like this behavior to be reflected to the `ms-vscode-remote.remote-containers/cloneInVolume` uri handler.

cc: @meeraharidasa

title: Explore UX for cell execution status for large code cells

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: notebook-execution
labels.description: Issues related to running cells in a notebook

body:
When executing a large code cell (ie more than a viewport height's worth of code), there isn't a great way to check the execution status (running, success, error). The cell execution count is sticky, so that will remain within the viewport, however it will increment regardless of the execution status.

Ideas to explore:
- color coding the execution status number
- sticky cell status bar
- other?

title: Github Copilot causing integrated terminal to not accept keyboard input (intermittently)

labels.name: new release
labels.description: Issues found in a recent release of VS Code

body:
Type: Bug 1. Install the Github Copilot extension (using free version) 2. With Git for Windows installed, setup the vscode terminal to point to git bash 3. Open the integrated terminal that's running git bash (I like bash better than cmd, but I don't like Windows subsystem, so I use minimal bash that comes with git for Windows) After navigating between windows (clicking explorer, navigate editor tabs, using terminal, i.e a daily workflow), after a short while, the terminal no longer takes input from the keyboard (i.e. keyboard input not echoing in the terminal). I have to restart vscode for it to work again. I've also noticed that sometimes it doesn't register the first character typed. For example, if I'm typing change directory command (e.g. cd my-directory), the "c" is not echoing on the terminal, only "d". Then if I backspace and try again, it works. So there's definitely something going on here. I have no other AI related extensions enabled, and the problem goes away when I disable the Github Copilot extension. When I try other AI assistant extensions like Cody, Continue, the terminal never freezes, so this is definitely a Github Copilot issue VS Code version: Code 1.99.2 (4949701c880d4bdb949e3c0e6b400288da7f474b, 2025-04-10T01:21:25.295Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19045 Modes:

title: Copilot suggest an appropriate model depending on a task/situation and other factors (e.g. constraints like rate limit or token size of the models)
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

There are external AI coding tools (forgot if it's Cline or Cursor or other) that can suggest or automatically switch to the appropriate model based on a task or situation or other factors like constraints on each model.

E.g. since there are rate limit on each model, it will be helpful for copilot to manage this bookkeeping and notify users their current consumption, and suggest other appropriate model to switch for their current task.
